description: Enterprise techniques used by Soft Cell, ATT&CK group G0093 v1.0
name: Soft Cell (G0093)

techniques.techniqueName: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
techniques.comment: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used Web shells and [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) for C2 as well as to exfiltrate data.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) ensured each payload had a unique hash, including by using different types of packers.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used dumped hashes to authenticate to other machines via pass the hash.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) collected data from the victim's local system, including password hashes from the SAM hive in the Registry.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers over the network as well as ping to identify remote systems.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) established VPN access into victim environments.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) compressed and staged files in multi-part archives in the Recycle Bin prior to exfiltration.

[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) in which they obfuscated strings such as debug messages in an apparent attempt to evade detection.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) to redirect connections between networks.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) packed some payloads using different types of packers, both known and custom.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) established persistence for [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) by created a scheduled task.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a renamed cmd.exe file to evade detection.

[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) dropped additional tools to victims during their operation, including portqry.exe, a renamed cmd.exe file, winrar, and [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040).
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used whoami and query user to obtain information about the victim user.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used netstat -oan to obtain information about the victim network connections.

[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used ipconfig /all to obtain information about the victim network configuration. The group also ran a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers.

[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) along with a PowerShell-based [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to dump credentials on the victim machines.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used reg commands to dump specific hives from the Windows Registry, such as the SAM hive, and obtain password hashes.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used the Windows command shell to execute commands.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used WMI for execution to assist in lateral movement as well as for installing tools across multiple assets.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used PowerShell for execution to assist in lateral movement as well as for dumping credentials stored on compromised machines.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used Web shells to persist in victim environments and assist in execution and exfiltration.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) created rogue, high-privileged domain user accounts to maintain access across waves of a compromise.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) leveraged valid accounts to maintain access to a victim network.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used DLL side-loading to covertly load [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) into memory on the victim machine.
[Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) exploited a publicly-facing server to gain access to the network.
